Well, I find it a lot crazier, that even while a DLP projector displays one color, all the pixels are turning on and off really quickly to display different shades of that color. Since the DLP chip consists of many many tiny mirrors that are electrostatically rotated to reflect the light out through the lens or not, the chip can only turn a pixel on or off but not a actually control the brightness. Therefore it uses pulse width modulation to fake different brightnesses. So on top of cycling through red, green and blue really quickly, even during the display period of one color the pixels are turned on and off many many times, but it's so quick that you really can't see it, not even if you move your eyes. And perhaps it's even crazier that the projector can even rotate these millions of tiny mirrors back and forth so damn quickly. I mean, they're absolutely tiny and weight pretty much nothing. But still, quite impressive.

Interesting fact about eye (improper laser safety) I damaged my eye with a 1/4w green laser. At first the damage showed as a black mark/shape where the laser hit. After a few months I had to try to see the damage the brain tended to make the damaged area show the same colors the eye saw near the damaged area. After a decade or so it seems the eye ignores what the damaged area sees (just like it does in the blind spot in the center of your eye where the optic nerve connects to the retina). Now the only way I see the blind spot is if I pick a small point like a light or sonething small in the distance and change where I'm looking untill the light disappears. Truly amazing how your perception can change so you dont see the damage. Lesson always use proper eye protection when using high power lasers, your vision is worth far more than good laser safety glasses.

This only works with DLP projectors as they work by flipping up mirrors to reflect light in a pattern that only does so one channel at a time, not all three at the same time. So with a 60Hz projector, you're actually seeing 180 images per second. First a red, then a green, then a blue, rinse and repeat.

With an LCD projector, all three channels are displayed at the same time, so you don't get that effect. These are more expensive solutions that require good image quality without any distractions. You do compromise on black levels, though.

The Persistence of Vision and the Phi Phenomena are the two physiological events that occur that make animation possible. To clarify, monitors and screens today only display red, green, and blue lights and the combination of them being on or off in 255 bits is what gives us the perceived color on them. The more pixels you have, the "finer" the colors can blend together to "trick" our eyes into seeing color and depth.

But the combination of the Persistence of Vision and Phi Phenomena is insane. Persistence of Vision keeps an image registered in your brain a little longer than it's actually there and then the Phi Phenomena is your brain predicting/filling in any missing images. Like when you blink while watching a movie, you can sometimes tell people what happened right when you blinked. This is because the Phi Phenomena predicted as best as it could what would happen between the last image you saw prior to the blink and what you see after.

As someone with highly light sensitive eyes, that demo in the beginning is mostly just painful. I very clearly see all the colours flicker and it's very disturbing. (Yes, in 1080p60, on a 60Hz synced display.) And yes, most DLP projectors have always been a problem for me due to the rainbow effect. Something else somewhat related you might want to look into is the PWM brightness regulation of most LED lights. This has long been a problem for people with light sensitive eyes, as what looked nicely uniform for the engineer, is just constant flicker to us, as it's been driven far too slowly.

Another interesting experiment is with LED lights and waving your hand rapidly. Some old (or low quality) LED lightbulbs have low frequency. When you wave your hand quickly below that light you will see separate images of your hand. Note that the LED lightbulb should be an only light source in the room.

This happens because LED lightbulbs (unlike traditional lightbulbs) do not emit a constant beam of light, they are actually flashing very quickly. When the light-flashing has low frequency the effect smooth movement is broken.

Another similar thing with digital clocks and 7-segment LED displays etc, if you ever notice that they appear to warp or flash when you move, it's because the whole number isn't really there. Almost always, the display will use what's known in the electrical engineering world as "multiplexing", where you flash a portion of the segments, change some internal stuff and flash different segments, etc until all the segments have been flashed, and repeat over and over hundreds of times per second. Try shaking your head side to side while looking at one or loudly rolling your R's at different speeds (if you can) to see some trippy light shows 😜

#everydaymysteries This video reminded me of a science teacher I had in middle school who had us look at a neighboring classmate's eyes while they were scanning from side to side, only moving their eyes. She explained that we cannot move our eyes 'smoothly' and our brain compensates for that to make us perceive a smooth scan. I noticed that she wasn't entirely correct about us not being able to move our eyes smoothly. You see very smooth motion of your eyes if you watch a still mirror as you rotate your head and keep your eyes fixed on themselves. She had also said we needed a partner, because you can never see your own eyes move with a mirror because you will be looking away from them as soon as you move them. My method disproved that as well, but does not allow you to see your own eyes move in the jerky motion.

My mystery would be: Why would our brain need the eyes to move in a jerky motion when scanning? I think it might be a clue that we actually see in sequences of still frames to simplify the processing of all that incoming data.

Your brain buffers information from the various senses, for approximately 80ms (longer, if you're very tall, shorter, if you are very short), so that it can process information arriving asynchronously, in a way that makes sense to your perception. If you simultaneously tap your head and your toe, you feel the stimulae simultaneously, even though the signal takes approximately 80ms longer to travel, from your toe. This relates to the saccades, in that when your eyes are in motion, your brain uses up the buffer and then 'pauses' the first stable image it sees, until the buffer is 'reloaded' and the new information can begin streaming to your consciousness.
We all live about 80ms 'in the past', in a literal sense.

Older LCD monitors and projectors from the 2000's take it one step further. Their Red, Green and Blue sub-pixels only had 64 different levels of brightness each (6 bits) rather than the typical 256 levels (8 bits). The latter could reproduce 16,777,216 different colors but the former could only do 262,144. In order to mimic 8 bit displays they rapidly flashed each pixel between several different values that averaged to the desired RGB result. Cheekily called a 'dithering' algorithm. Those things lied to your eyes twice.

It´s not only projectors that rely on persistance of vision, the good old cathode ray tube also creates only parts of the image for a small fraction of time, but what you see is a complete image. Furthermore what´s also fascinating is the way how the brain controls the eyes´ movement. That includes an essential feedback signal that goes from the areas of the brain that coordinate the movement to the actual visual systems to prevent the image of the outside world from jumping around when changing your visual focus. This only works when the extraocular muscles are actively involved in moving the eyeball. Poking your eye with your finger (only through your eyelid!!!) will cause the image to tilt or skip, because the visual system doesn´t get the right feedback to correct for  the movement.

I don't get what they found in study.
Persistence of vision for me is enough to explain all effects except may be clock.
Why you see gradients when you move eyes with same speed - persistence of vision explains well.
Why you don't see how your eyes moving: it's either you have other eye far in peripheral vision, or it's too small to see details (mirror far away).
In first case: you don't notice because it's blured in peripheral vision, and when you move point of view for a long distance you are losing reference picture to compare with, to see difference.
It is illusion that if something is standing still and you look over it, then precieved picture is not moving too.
If you pay attention on what you see when you're moving eyes in static envirovment then you'll see that what you see is also moving.
We are so used to it, so we're not noticing it. But here position of eyes changes simultaneously with losing the reference.
And when new reference is received it's already too late.

Also, simple model of what you see is: two black circles on some distance, then very quickly they both shift so one of them appears in place where another was. During the shift, one cricle gradualy fading out, and fading in, in another place. And there are two barely noticable grey circles which is moving, and this is what you expecting to see - moving circles (eyes).
But you don't, because they are barely noticable grey, because it's cumulative effect of persistence of vision.
When you was looking at some eye before switching to another - you can think of it as picture accumulated to 100%,
then after very fast shift only very tiny amount of time passed, and not much accumulated by eyes, and then eyes started to accumulate new picture from the moment when move was ended (this is why other circle is appearing).

In second case you have mirror too far away and reflection of eyes is too small to notice movement, because movement of eyes is also small too. But all effects are same: losing reference, fade-out/fade-in (disappear/appear), unnoticable ghost of previous picture.

Theoretically, there is possibility that you may find distance between eyes and mirror where you able to notice eyes movement.
When I was experimenting on this after Steve Mould video about it, I thought that I have found distance like that.
But today I have checked it once again, and nope, I can't notice eyes movement.
However I have noticed that if you cross eyes you can see how eyes moving if distance between mirror and face is not large.
In this way you can approximate distance where you may see enough by peripheral vision.
Also it's way to see how much eyes are moving depending on distance between mirror and your face.

Visual retention not only blends the frames of a movie together giving us the impression of continuous movement, it also retains color for a length of time, and when it is refreshed with a different color the brain doesn't have time to separate the colors, but merges them into one new, blended color. If you move your eyes across a flashing image or light source whether it's a different frame of a movie or a blinking light such as an LED tail light, or in this case separate colors alternately flashing, moving your eye exposes a new, fresh patch of retina to the second flash, and it will not be blended with the first, thus tracers are seen, separate colored tracers, or separate images that look jittery. It's because the fresh part of the retina is getting the next image, not the same patch of retina that just saw the previous image so your brain cannot merge them. I notice this terribly with LED tail lights, because LED lights cannot be dimmed. Instead they simply begin to flash the light so it's just as bright, but on only half the time, giving your brain the impression that the light is half as bright. However if you move your eye across the field you will easily see the blinks as they track across your retina and it drives me CRAZY it is distracting and dangerous in traffic.

Another fun thing to try that I'm pretty sure relates to this:

1. Get a string of incandescent Christmas lights and a strand of LED Christmas lights.
2. Plug them both in.
3. Stare at them and shake them.

The incandescent bulbs will have nice continuous motion blur lines, but the LED bulbs appear to jump between locations.

My theory is that the incandescent bulbs are always on, but the LED ones flicker. (Probably at 60hz or 50hz depending on where you live. I'm guessing this is due to the fact that they are plugged into an AC outlet but diodes only allow current to flow one way, but I'm not sure.) So since the LEDs are not always on they do not have smooth motion blur lines and look weird when you shake them.

This reminded me of a related visual effect I noticed a while back.
About 10 or so years ago, I noticed that while driving at night I would see dotted lines connected to the red tail lights of cars in front of me. I realized that the dots occurred when I shifted my eyesight from one car to another in front of me (a saccade). It only happened on certain car models and I presume that this is because the lights were pulse modulated to control the brightness.
I have noticed in more recent years that this effect happens less frequently. I guess that the effect was bothering people and car manufacturers stopped using the pulse modulation.

Note: This is only an issue for single-chip DLP (digital light processing) projectors.

In these projectors, a SINGLE imaging DMD-chip (digital mirror device; a chip containing a small mirror for every pixel in the image) is used to generate the image on the screen.
It works like this: Pure white light is emitted from a lamp. The light is filtered through a colour wheel. The wheel is made from red, green and blue light filters, and some times more colours are used to help generate more precise colours in the final image. These colours could be yellow, dark green and white. As the red-filtered light hits the DMD, the little mirrors are adjusted to the levels needed for the red sub-pixels, then as wheel turns to the green filter, the DMD switches the mirrors to the levels needed for the green sub-pixels, and then the blue...

LCD and LCOS based projectors, are usually outfitted with three imaging chips, splitting the light into its primary colours using stationary filters or prisms. Each chip is then used as dedicated red, green or blue imaging chip. The output light from these chips are then realigned optically using prisms. With these projectors the effects is not present, since all three colours hit the screen simultaneously.

Projectors and other technology work this way because the human eye does. The human eye only sees three bands of light centered on red, green, and blue (cones). Off center colors trigger two cones, eg yellow triggers the red and green cones at the same time and we perceive this as yellow. Our technology is designed to exploit this. See this chart from Wikipedia: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/94/1416_Color_Sensitivity.jpg

the rainbow effect on the projectors is due to lower end "DLP" projectors. In order to keep prices down, the projector is built to flash each color component at a time. Higher end projectors use 3 separate lamps with R G B filters to create a single image instead of 3 fast frames one for each R G B.

The LCD Clock thing is called Multiplexing, and it's a really common way of using less connections to drive each segment of each 7-segment digit.
